facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 3, 1956 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 48 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 3, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 48 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 6, 1962 by Wanchoo J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 6. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-

facts.text: Certain decretal moneys deposited in the then Chief Court of Oudh at Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. Certain decretal moneys were deposited in the then Chief Court of Oudh at Lucknow.

facts.text: Respondents applied to Chief Court for permission to withdraw moneys on furnishing security and were permitted.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents applied to the Chief Court for permission to withdraw the moneys on furnishing security and were permitted to do so.

facts.text: Registered security bond executed and registered in Simla in 1949 by which a house there was given in security.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon a registered security bond was executed and registered in Simla in 1949 by which a house there was given in security for withdrawal of the money.

facts.text: Inspector of Stamps reported on March 15, 1950 that security bond was mortgage deed without possession, insufficiently stamped.

anchor.surface_text: Befere, however, the money companyld be withdrawn, the Inspector of Stamps reported on March 15, 1950, that the so called security bond was in reality a mortgage deed without possession and was insufficiently stamped.

facts.text: Inspector reported deficit stamp duty of Rs. 482/11/- and penalty of Rs. 4,826/14/- should be levied.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore reported that it should be impounded and the deficit stamp duty of Rs. 482/11/- and a penalty amounting to Rs. 4,826/14/- should be levied with respect to that document.

facts.text: On April 5, 1950, Deputy Commissioner, Kheri, acting as Collector passed order allowing parties to put objections in writing to Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon on April 5, 1950, the Deputy Commissioner, Kheri, acting as Collector passed the following order - In case the parties have any objection, they put it in writing which will be referred to the Board of Revenue.

facts.text: On July 5, 1950, respondents objected that document was not a mortgage deed, no duty or penalty payable, and it was tentative.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that on July 5, 1950, the respondents objected that the document was number a mortgagedeed and that, numberduty or penalty was payable, and further that as the document had number been till then accepted by the companyrt,. it was only a tentative document.

facts.text: On August 3, 1950, judicial officer impounded security bond under s.33 of Indian Stamp Act and forwarded to Deputy Commissioner under s.38.

anchor.surface_text: On August 3, 1950, the judicial officer before whom the security bond was filed impounded it under s. 33 of the Indian Stamp Act, No. If of 1898,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , and apparently forwarded it to the Deputy Commissioner, Kheri, under s. 38 of the Act.

facts.text: In November 1950, respondents filed further objections before Treasury Officer, Kheri.

anchor.surface_text: It seems thereafter that in November 1950 the respondents filed further objections before Stamp Officer  TreaBury Officer , Kheri,

facts.text: In December 1950, Treasury Officer reported Inspector's view correct, duty and penalty due; no hearing given to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1950, the Treasury Officer made a report to the effect that the view of the Inspector of Stamps was companyrect and duty and penalty. as reported by the latter were due. The respondents case was that the Treasury Officer did number give them any hearing before making the said report.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner made order 'Realise'; no hearing given to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that on this report the Deputy Commissioner made the order Realise. He also is said to have given numberhearing to the respondents.

facts.text: In January 1951, respondents filed revision against Deputy Commissioner's order before Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1951, the respondents filed a revision against the order of the Deputy Commissioner before the Board of Revenue.

facts.text: In March 1951, Deputy Commissioner referred matter to Board of Revenue under s.56(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears however that in March 1951 the Deputy Commissioner referred the matter to the Board of Revenue under s. 56 2  of the Act.

facts.text: In July 1951, Board of Revenue upheld Collector's order; no hearing given to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In July 1951 the Board of Revenue disposed of the matter and upheld the order of the Collector. But the respondents companylaint was that the Board of Revenue also did number give them a hearing.

facts.text: In November 1951, respondents filed writ petition in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently they filed a writ petition in the High Court in November 1951.

facts.text: Single Judge dismissed writ petition holding no provision for hearing under Act or Rules.

anchor.surface_text: That petition was dismissed by the learned Single Judge on the ground that neither the Act number the Rules made thereunder provided that any bearing should be given to the person who was liable to pay the deficit stamp duty and the penalty.

facts.text: Single Judge held Collector gave opportunity via writing, Board considered revision grounds, no personal hearing required.

anchor.surface_text: He further held that in any case the Collector had given an opportunity to the respondents to urge their objections in writing, and that the Board of Revenue had also companysidered the grounds taken by the respondents in their revision-petition and there was numberprovision in the law requiring the Board of Revenue to give a personal hearing or a hearing through companynsel in a case of this kind.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court appeal court set aside Board order for no hearing, applying natural justice principles.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal companyrt therefore held that the authorities companycerned when acting either under s. 40 or s. 56 were number acting judicially or quasi judicially. The appeal companyrt further held that even though the authorities were acting merely administratively under a. 40 and s. 56 2  they were bound to give a hearing according to the principles of natural justice

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds High Court order on ground that Board acts quasi-judicially under s.56(2) and must give hearing.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore uphold the order of the high Court, though on a different ground.

On August 3, 1950, the judicial officer before whom the security bond was filed impounded it under s. 33 of the Indian Stamp Act, No. If of 1898,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , and apparently forwarded it to the Deputy Commissioner, Kheri, under s. 38 of the Act.

On August 3, 1950, the judicial officer before whom the security bond was filed impounded it under s. 33 of the Indian Stamp Act, No. If of 1898,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , and apparently forwarded it to the Deputy Commissioner, Kheri, under s. 38 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the Board of Revenue when dealing with a proceeding under s. 56 2  of the Act acts administratively or quasi-judicially

anchor.surface_text: A similar question arises in the present appeal, viz., whether the Board of Revenue when dealing with a proceeding under s. 56 2  of the Act acts administratively or quasi-judicially.

issues.text: whether the Board of Revenue was bound under the principles of natural justice to give a hearing to the respondents when proceeding under s.56 2  of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellant before us is that the High Court having held that the Board was acting merely administratively when proceeding under s.56  2  of the Act went wrong in holding that it was bound under the principles of natural justice to give a hearing to the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Let us therefore first look to the scheme which leads up to the reference under s. 56 2  of the Act. That sub-section provides that if any Collector, acting under s. 31, s.40 or s.41, feels doubt as to the amount of duty with which any instrument is chargeable,

arguments.claim: question whether an authority acts judicially is to be gathered from express provisions of the Act; if silent, from cumulative effect of nature of rights affected, manner of disposal, objective criterion, phraseology, indicia

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by us in C.A. 132 of 1959, the question whether an authority, like the Board of Revenue, acts judicially is to be gathered from the express provisions of the Act, in the first instance. Where however the provisions of the Act are silent, the duty to act judicially may be inferred

arguments.claim: considering nature of duty under s.56(2) to construe instruments and apply Act resulting in heavy duty and penalty, legislature intended Board to hear person before imposing liability

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us, companysidering the nature of the duty cast on the Board of Revenue under s.56 2  requiring it to companystrue instruments submitted to it thereunder and the application of the Act to them which may result in payment of heavy amounts of deficit duty and even heavier amounts as penalty,

arguments.claim: s.57 shows questions under s.56(2) may be referred to High Court for judicial decision by three judges, hence hearing under s.56(2) also judicial

anchor.surface_text: Further, s.57 enforces the above companyclusion. That section provides that the Chief Controlling Revenue-authority may state any case referred to it under s.56 2 , or otherwise companying to its numberice. and refer such case, with its own opinion thereon to the High Court,

arguments.claim: Board has to act judicially when proceeding under s.56(2) and must on principles of natural justice give a hearing to the other party

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that, companysidering the totality of circumstances and the nature of the matter to be determined by the Board of Revenue under s.56 2 , the Board has to act judicially when proceeding under s.56 2  and must therefore on principles of natural justice give a hearing to the other party,

holdings.text: The Board of Revenue has to act judicially (quasi-judicially) when proceeding under s.56(2) of the Indian Stamp Act

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by us in C.A. 132 of 1959, the question whether an authority, like the Board of Revenue, acts judicially is to be gathered from the express provisions of the Act, in the first instance. Where however the provisions of the Act are silent, the duty to act judicially may be inferred from the provisions of the statute or may be gathered from the cummulative effect of the nature of the rights affected, the manner of the disposal provided, the objective criterion to be adopted, the phraseology used and other indicia afforded by the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express provisions silent on hearing; inferred from statutory scheme (ss.31,40,41 leading to reference on doubt re duty/construction), nature of function (legal question, heavy liability/penalty), s.57 reference to High Court, applying test from C.A. 132/1959 on indicia of judicial action

holdings.text: The Board of Revenue must give a hearing to the affected party on principles of natural justice when acting under s.56(2)

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that, companysidering the totality of circumstances and the nature of the matter to be determined by the Board of Revenue under s.56 2 , the Board has to act judicially when proceeding under s.56 2  and must therefore on principles of natural justice give a hearing to the other party, namely, the executant of the instrument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial function requires natural justice hearing despite no statutory provision; affects rights via pecuniary liability; legislature intended hearing before imposing duty/penalty

holdings.text: The Board of Revenue acts as a quasi-judicial body under s.56(2) and respondents were entitled to a hearing before it

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Revenue therefore, acts as a quasi-judicial body under s. 56 2  and the respondents were entitled to a hearing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct conclusion from analysis of s.56(2) function and natural justice requirements

holdings.text: High Court order upheld though on different ground (Board order set aside for no hearing)

anchor.surface_text: We therefore uphold the order of the high Court, though on a different ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agree with result (violation of hearing requirement) but hold Board quasi-judicial under s.56(2), not merely administrative bound by natural justice

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by us in C.A. 132 of 1959, the question whether an authority, like the Board of Revenue, acts judicially is to be gathered from the express provisions of the Act, in the first instance. Where however the provisions of the Act are silent, the duty to act judicially may be inferred from the provisions of the statute or may be gathered from the cummulative effect of the nature of the rights affected, the manner of the disposal provided, the objective criterion to be adopted, the phraseology used and other indicia afforded by the statute.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that, companysidering the totality of circumstances and the nature of the matter to be determined by the Board of Revenue under s.56 2 , the Board has to act judicially when proceeding under s.56 2  and must therefore on principles of natural justice give a hearing to the other party, namely, the executant of the instrument.
